title: Concerts I've been to
name: Concerts I've been to
description:
A Map by Wept

Concerts that I've been to over the years.

properties.name: Audiovariancision, Atomic Cafe, circa 1997
properties.description: Posted by Wept   8005 E. Roosevelt, scottsdale, azAn amazing performance by Trent the Audio Architect of audiovariancision. This performance really had an incredible impact on my view of live performance as well as musical appreciation and creation in general. His music\'s incredible mix of electronic, industrial and tribal elements still amaze me to this day. I felt as if the one thing that was lacking from this show was a huge bon-fire in the middle of the place to dance around. And I don\'t mean that in a cheesy way at all. Simply amazing. The third best show I have ever seen in my life.

properties.name: Broken Fabiola, The Vogue, January 6th, 2005
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1516 11th Avenue, Seattle, WA, 98122Broken Fabiola is a side project of the more angry project "Manufactura" by Karloz .M. I was very, very pleasantly surprised at how chill and great it was. The show was basically Karloz behind a sheet which had live video creations displayed on it. It was very low key, and the music was nuanced and great. The music was the kind of thing which takes you on a journey listening to it, and many times throughout the show I would find myself closing my eyes and letting it take me wherever it was going to. I even bought the album at the show, which is not very common for me. I shook his hand after the show and thanked him.

properties.name: Erasure, Moore Theatre, July 24th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1932 2nd Ave., Seattle, WA, United StatesVery stressful trip up to Seattle to make it in time - had to cut out early of a tutorial at the Ubuntu Live conference to make it, and even then we cut it very short. Ended up timing it almost perfectly - the show started about 10 minutes after we arrived. When we first got in the venue I noticed it was about 20 degrees hotter in there than outside. Grrrreat! My wife had gotten me tickets to this sold-out show for my birthday. I was initially excited but, as always, ready for the show to be a complete flop (because so many are.) I was very pleasantly removed of that concern in short order. They played a few tracks from their new album (yes, they actually do have a new album - and it\'s actually good!), and they played a lot of their old hits. Chains of love, blue savannah, Drama!, almost every damn thing off of their "Pop 20 Hits" album (although not You Surround Me, which is my favorite - ah well). Despite the fact that they aren\'t exactly young anymore, they were still great showman and Andy Bell had more energy than most 20-somethings. The outfits he/they wore and the stage was just straight out of the 80s - it was hilarious. This show is definitely in my top 10 list of shows. After a while, I stopped caring that it was about 20000 degrees inside. Side note: after a very bad experience after a Skinny Puppy concert where I thought that I had permanent hearing damage, I am a real nazi about wearing earplugs at all concerts I attend. Surprisingly the music was mixed so well and the levels were so perfect, I rarely felt I needed to wear my earplugs - except, for when the songs were over. The crowd was so goddamn loud and insane (and the average age was around mid-30s, maybe even 40s! I think we were some of the youngest people there.) I have been to many-a-Morrissey show, who has a legendary cult following, but this crowd was about 10x more insanely in love with Andy Bell than the crowds I\'ve seen for Morrissey. Unbelievable, I know...but true! Side note 2: The photo below seems to actually be of the stage in Seattle, or at least very similar.

properties.name: Faithless, The Fillmore, April 30 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept1805 Geary Blvd, San Francisco, CADespite having the worst hotel room on earth and screwing up my knee from walking up and down San Francisco\'s hills before the concert, this concert was great. The venue was very nice, and we were able to be about 10 feet from the stage. Faithless sells out huge venues in Europe, and seeing them in this much smaller setting was something that I don\'t think very many people get to see. There were some people who actually flew from England to see them at this show and it seemed like they were about to die of excitement. One note: even though its pretty fun to be in the front during a concert, the sound is not very good in the very front for obvious reasons. I don\'t think I would want to be that close for a concert again. Crappy quality video clip from the show:

properties.name: Finally saw Skinny Puppy here.  Roseland
properties.description: Posted by Wept  8 Northwest 6th Avenue, Portland, OR, 97209After a failed attempt to travel to see them in Dresden, Germany for their reunion performance, I finally saw them a bit closer to home. Although they played a few newer songs which I don\'t exactly enjoy, it was incredible to finally see them in person. A band which has influenced me more than any other musically, personally, emotionally and a lot more... Seeing them live and in person was an unexplainable joy. Although I think the show would have been even better had I caught them in their prime (at least during the Last Rights era), it was still great. A checkbox checked off of my "list of things I have to do before I die." Oh, also, my ears rang for literally a week afterward. As a music fiend, it scared me more than anything ever has. I have worn ear plugs at every show I\'ve been to ever since.

properties.name: Hallucinogen/Shpongle, The Fenix Underground, June 16, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept109 S Washington St, Seattle, WAThis concert was originally supposed to also feature younger brother, which would have been fucking awesome judging by the video at the bottom (not to mention the album they have released!) Unfortunately one of the guys from YB cancelled at the last minute, and so we got KoxBox instead, which was really quite terrible. Not only was he terrible, but he wouldn\'t get off the stage for Simon Posford. WTF? The hallucinogen set was good - I\'m not a huge hallucinogen fan but it was enjoyable anyway. The shpongle set was unfortunately a DJ only set, probably because the other half of Shpongle didn\'t want to venture over to this side of the ocean. All in all a very good show despite Koxbox and the lack of Younger Brother. A band I never thought I would see live. Posford has definitely done way too many drugs, but it seems like he is very happy about it anyway. Younger brother live at brixton: Actual clip from hallucinogen in seattle:

properties.name: Meat Beat Manifesto, Nuemos, June 10th, 2005
properties.description: Posted by Wept 925 E Pike St, Seattle, WAThis place was incredibly loud, and not in a good way. Luckily by this time, I had had a very scary experience with hearing loss at the Skinny Puppy show and was wearing earplugs. The coolest part of this show was that they had a video screen that was playing all of the videos from which they got their samples, at the right time in the song. The bad part of the show was that it was BOOOORRRRIINNNGGG. They even seemed bored! My wife and I ended up leaving after about 4 songs. Shame, really... I have(had?) admired MBM for over a decade.

properties.name: Ministry, Mesa Ampitheater, March 11, 19
properties.description: Posted by WeptMesa, AZYou know, given Ministry\'s hardcore appearance, I think this might be surprising. But, one word can sum up this show: BORING. Back to the drugs, Al! He also continually insulted the audience. Classy. The best part of this show was the after-show show at The Nile Theater in Mesa, AZ. N17 played which was great, but there was this other band whose name I don\'t remember. Their vocalist\'s main tactic was just screaming (and I really mean SCREAMING) unintelligible things into the microphone. As annoying as it might sound, it was actually very interesting and cool to me at the time. He got so into it he accidentally fell of the stage, and then just continued to yell into the microphone in the fetal position on the floor. Thumbs up for that guy! At least he wasn\'t boring! This crazy guy kept asking me, "how many decibles do you think that\'s putting out?!"

properties.name: Morrissey, Paramount Theatre, May 6th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept 911 Pine St., Seattle, WA, United StatesWhat can be said? Morrissey just keeps getting better and better. Unexpectedly fucking amazing rendition of "Life is a Pigsty" which made me wish yet again that my eyeballs had a record button. The encore of "Please, please, please let me get what I want" could make a grown man cry. I was actually expecting this concert to be not so great. Morrissey is getting older, his latest album wasn\'t that great, etc. But, I\'ve seen Morrissey 4 or 5 times now, and I have to say that this, as a whole, was probably the best show I\'ve ever seen from him. There are few musicians who can maintain the quality of their music and performance this long, luckily for me Morrissey is one of them! Life is a pigsty (in Zagreb):

properties.name: Sleeping with the Earth, Baltic Room, 2005
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1207 Pine Street, Seattle, WA, 98101At the entrance to this show, they gave out ear plugs. This should have been the first warning signal. In addition to the normal club speakers, they had erected an additional set of at least two more speakers. It was REALLY loud. I can\'t possibly explain how loud it was to do it justice. The opening DJs were so horrible that we stayed outside for most of it. When SWTE came on, the bass was so incredibly loud and strong that it literally made me physically sick from shaking my insides. It was like riding a really psychotic rollercoaster. Eventually I decided I could not physically stand it anymore, and we left. Unfortunate, because I really do like SWTE and I enjoyed the music - it was simply too loud. Perhaps, that makes me too old!

properties.name: Snog, Paris Theater, circa August 24th, 2001
properties.description: Posted by Wept 6 Sw 3rd Avenue, Portland, OR, 97204The opening bands for this show were so terrible I had to go outside. Snog wasn\'t all that great either, through no fault of their own. The sound at the Paris is notoriously terrible, and really all I heard was a horrible wall of sound. Too bad. I really like Snog.

properties.name: The Cure, America West Arena, August 18th, 1996
properties.description: Posted by Wept  400 West Washington Street, Phoenix, AZ, 85003This is, by far, the best concert I\'ve ever been to. The Cure had no opening bands, and they played for 3 hours straight. It was as perfect as could possibly be wished for. Their long version of "A Forest" was unbelievably amazing. It was one of those concerts where I could look around, and everyone in the place was as happy as they could possibly be. They played a LOT of their old material, as well. It was truly great. A not so great story that accompanies this concert is this one: To get tickets, I sat outside a mall for hours, starting the night before. There were about 5 people ahead of me. Because it was so damn hot outside, my friends and I took turns driving around the mall in the air conditioned car so that we wouldn\'t die. Anyhow, around the time the doors are about to open this hick pulls up, gives this guy that\'s been waiting in line some sum of money, and takes his place in line. Weird, I think. The doors finally open, we rush to the ticket counter, and this bastard isn\'t even buying tickets to The Cure, he\'s buying tickets for some goddamn country concert! AND, he\'s clearly a scalper. He is not just buying one, he is buying like 30, and he wants to hand-pick these seats. I was closer to murder that day than probably any moment in my entire life. Seriously. I was indescribably pissed off. Each seat that he picked to his crappy ass country concert was taking the time equivalent to a full row of Cure being wasted away. By the time I got to order my tickets, I still got floor seats, but very far in the back. Some people I knew who were waiting at another mall to get tickets that were similarly placed in line, but did not have said ticket scalper in front of them, got 2nd or 3rd row seats. I was so, very, very, very, very, very, very, very angry. It is something that can still get me extremely pissed off if I think about it for too long, and it was 10 years ago!

properties.name: Toad the Wet Sprocket, McMenamins Crystal Ballroom, August 13th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept1332 W Burnside St, Portland, ORThis band probably seems very odd to be placed among the others in this map, but ah well. TTWS is a band I\'ve loved since I was a kid, and since they broke up I thought I\'d never see them. About 5 days before this concert I saw on the Crystal Ballroom\'s marquee that they were playing and we got tickets - I didn\'t even know they had come back together to tour or anything, so it was a nice surprise. The concert was great - not anything mindblowing (they are just kind of a folk-rock band afterall), but really just....good. Some of their songs were ones that I played a lot during certain parts of my life, and it was nice to hear them played live. Not in my top 10 list or anything, but certainly a show I am very glad I went to. And yet another show where we were some of the youngest people in the audience. Woo! A clip of them playing "Windmills", one of my favorite songs, live (not at the show I went to, and not that great of quality, but "it\'s toad!")

properties.name: Tricky, Roseland Theater, August 3rd, 2001
properties.description: Posted by Wept  8 Northwest 6th Avenue, Portland, OR, 97209This was the second time I saw Tricky. The first was in or near Scottsdale, AZ and I have to admit that I wasn\'t that impressed. This time, however, it was a completely different experience. When Tricky was performing, it felt like his presence filled the entire room. When he performed "Tear Out My Eyes", it literally made my jaw drop. His band was also amazing, particularly the drummer. This show renewed my faith in Tricky and ultimately, upon reflection, led me to the ultimate belief that Tricky is simply a badass mother (shut yo mouth!).

properties.name: Underworld at the Warfield, San Francisco 1999 - The best concert I've ever been to
properties.description: Posted by Wept san francisco, caI flew down from Portland to see this show, and I am so glad that I did. This is during the tour that resulted in the amazing "Everything, Everything" DVD/CD. The performers fed off of the energy of the audience, the audience fed off of the energy of the performers, and it was a wonderfully intense feedback loop. They played a version of "Rowla" that was beyond anything I\'ve ever experienced musically. This guy who was dressed in a suit, sweaty as hell from dancing, kept looking back at one of his friends and saying "I can\'t believe this!!". I couldn\'t have put it better.

properties.name: VNV Nation, Hawthorne Theater, June 29th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1507 SE 39th St. Portland, OregonWell, unfortunately we made a horrible mistake in trying to skip the opening bands and showed up to find VNV playing their last song of the evening (before the encore). Ah well. I\'ve seen them twice before, and like Covenant, it\'s always a good show. The venue was ridiculous though - could the layout get any worse? There was a bar literally right in the middle of the floor. Who the hell thought that was a good idea? Let\'s ruin 1/4th of the viewing space! Awesome! VNV Nation\'s Kingdom live:
